content:
I asked this question many weeks ago but asking again in case anything has changed with Lean/Mathlib.

I'm developing a set of beginner-oriented educational examples. To minimise cognitive load I wanted to have the same simple "import" at the beginning of the examples, and only change that later when it really becomes necessary.

Based on the previous discussion I used 

import Mathlib.Tactic

as a simple import that brings in most tactics and definitions needed. In 12 tutorials I haven't needed to change this.

Today I saw a simple example that had:

import Mathlib

Is this now the recommended "simple starter" import that brings in the most common definitions and tactics?

What's changed if this is indeed the case.

If you want to get everything that mathlib has to offer, then import Mathlib is what you want.
I would recommend going with that.
i think the main reason people use import Mathlib is because it very consistently imports almost anything even an expert might want. For beginners it can be overkill...

In my experience, import Mathlib.Tactic should be fine for the kind of mathematics that you're doing. This is my default import for when I'm teaching 1st year undergrad maths in my class, although I move up to import Mathlib when we're doing more nontrivial stuff like 3rd year modules. The disadvantage of import Mathlib is that then there are so many theorems imported that tactics like exact? can take much longer to work. I would experiment with import Mathlib.Tactic but my guess is that this will be fine for you.
I'll continue with import Mathlib.Tactic as per Kevin's reasoning.
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.
